title: What’s Okay for Someone in Authority to Ask?

legend.amber: It depends. Needs context or a conversation.

scenarios.scenario: Someone senior asks you to grab them lunch while you’re out getting your own.
prompts: Does this feel friendly and mutual, or does it make you feel like “the help”?
Would your answer change if it happened regularly?

scenarios.scenario: At 6 p.m., someone in a position of authority messages: “Can you rework these slides tonight so we’re ready for the 9 a.m. exec review?”
prompts: When is this fair teamwork under pressure — and when does it become poor planning or boundary overreach?

scenarios.scenario: After a workshop, someone senior asks you to tidy the room, collect Post-its, and take out the rubbish while they rush to another meeting.
prompts: Is this shared responsibility, or is hierarchy showing through?
What’s the right way to handle moments like this?

scenarios.scenario: A senior colleague asks you to book a restaurant for their anniversary or collect a parcel that was delivered to the office.
prompts: This one’s outside the job description — but would you still feel able to say no?
What’s the risk if you say yes?

scenarios.scenario: You get a message on Saturday: “Can you just check that the homepage metrics updated?”
prompts: Is it okay if it’s a one-off?
Where should we draw the line between flexibility and respecting downtime?

scenarios.scenario: Someone senior says: “I trust you to own this one fully.”
prompts: When does this feel empowering — and when does it feel like being set up to take the blame?
What does true ownership look like?

scenarios.scenario: You’re asked to represent a senior colleague in a meeting and speak on their behalf.
prompts: A great growth opportunity or an uncomfortable substitute?
What needs to be in place for this to feel safe and empowering?

scenarios.scenario: Someone in a position of hierarchy tells you to keep quiet about a decision that directly affects your peers.
prompts: Is that trust and discretion, or manipulation and secrecy?
How do you know when it crosses the line?
